オプション1: (My head hurts... My nose hurts... The soles of my feet hurt...)
He kept repeating the cycle of sitting down and walking again and again.
Star Man sat and looked at his left arm. It had turned dark red and black.
(It doesn't hurt as much as it looks.)
Birdsong went on without a break.

(It'd be nice if I could catch a bird and eat it,
 but there's no way. If I could take eggs from a nest, I would...)
(I've never once found a bird's nest in my life...)
Star Man looked up, searching for oak trees.

(Probably... You can't pick up acorns year‑round,
 so I'll have to find other foods at some point.
 How long do acorns keep? They seem like they'd store well.)

A heavy impact—<THUD>—hit Star Man.
He looked around in a panic; his body was on fire.

Not knowing what was happening, Star Man rolled around on the ground.
Even rolling and throwing dirt on himself wouldn't put out the flames.
At length the fire went out on its own.

He had suffered severe burns; smoke rose from his body.
Star Man couldn't grasp the situation, but he had a premonition he would not survive.

Looking around, he saw a semi‑transparent, human‑shaped thing slowly drawing near.
...Flames appeared from the ghost's hand, and when it swung, the fire flew toward Star Man.
"What the...?!"
The human‑shaped thing was passing through trees and rocks as it came toward him.

Star Man tried to flee, but managing a few steps was the best he could do.
His strength gave out and he dropped to his knees.
Looking back, the ghost was slowly approaching.

The ghost reached out its hand. It looked about to do something,
 but he could no longer even move.
Flames appeared from the ghost's hand and flew toward Star Man with a flick.
Unable to dodge, Star Man was burned all over by the flames.
Star Man collapsed and couldn't move a millimeter.
(So this is the end...)

He closed his eyes.
In the darkness, he could hear only his own heartbeat.

Events strongly imprinted in his past
floated up in Star Man's mind.
Not a single good thing came to mind.

(Me... I failed at everything...
In the end, I never became anything...)
<VROOOOM>

A black vortex appeared before Star Man with a deep bass rumble.
From it stepped a person whose face was an animal skull.
Large horns sprouted from the skull.

With this new "monster" appearing, Star Man wanted to run,
but his body wouldn't move.
The horned person held out a hand.
"I'll be brief."

"If you make a contract with me, you'll be saved and gain tremendous power.
However, you'll die in one year. Well?"

"...If you make a contract with me, you'll be saved and gain tremendous power.
However, you'll die in one year. Well?"
The ghost was drawing nearer.
"What... is that...?"
Star Man forced out the words.
"The ghost of a human who once lived on this island."
"If I make the contract... will these burns be healed...?"
"Yes."
"I'll make the contract."
"The contract is sealed."
The horned person produced two small vials.
"This is WordBress. Drink it and, even if you die, you'll revive here."
"And the burns...?"
"They won't heal just by drinking... They'll be healed when you revive."
(So I have to die once...)

"Don't worry. Strictly speaking, when you're on the verge of death,
your body will be restored and you'll be returned here. If you truly die, it's no good."
"And you can revive only once per bottle of WordBress."
"For now... I'll drink one..."
The horned person nodded.
"Shall I help you drink it?"
"Please..."

The horned person opened the WordBress and poured it into Star Man's mouth.
Summoning his last strength, Star Man swallowed the liquid.
He felt something settle inside him.

"Also, from here on you'll be able to use magic—fire, ice, and darkness.
That ghost can only be attacked with dark magic."
"Like this."

The horned person faced a palm toward the ghost.
Black flames shot toward it and struck home.
The black flame shattered and scattered; the ghost writhed and then vanished.

The horned person looked at Star Man, paused a moment,
then formed an ice spear on their palm.
"Want me to bring you back without suffering...?"

(I'm not going to make it anyway...
If this pain is going to continue...)
Star Man didn't even have the strength to answer. He gave a small nod.
<THUD! THUD!>
The ice spear pierced Star Man's neck and chest.
Star Man fell to the ground. His eyes stayed open and he stopped blinking.
Star Man woke up.
An ice spear lay before him. The part that had pierced his body was gone.
The horned person stood in front of him.
(It wasn't a dream...)
Star Man checked the state of his body.
(Everything really is healed.)
"Th‑thank you."
"You're welcome."
Star Man still had one unopened WordBress in his hand.
(...Should I drink this right now?)
"If months pass after I drink the vial and I die after that, does it still work?"
"Yes. But if you drink now, the place you revive will be here."

"I see. I need to choose carefully where to drink it...
Can I give it to someone else?"
"You can, but only the person who made the contract gets the effect."
Star Man stared at the WordBress.
(I need to take good care of this last one...)

"I once gave about a thousand to the islanders.
There should be some unused WordBress left here and there."
"I see..."
"For a fine point: even if you drink two at once, it only counts once."

"Also, even if your head is blown off you can revive.
However, in that case, skills and memories are not restored.
You won't know who you are, can't use your smartphone, and won't understand words."
"...I see."
"That's all."
The horned person summoned a black vortex and started to leave.
"...Thank you."
"No problem."
"Why did you help me?"

"Because I want a contract.
Not many people will agree to a contract that kills them in a year.
I inevitably appear before those on the verge of death."
"I see."
"For the record, that ghost earlier isn't in cahoots with me."
"O‑okay."
(No way to verify that, though...)
"...Farewell, then."
The horned person returned into the black vortex.
Star Man walked toward the forest where the acorns grew.
(...Only one year left to live...)

His body was fully recovered, but Star Man lost the will to do anything.
He sat on a fallen tree and looked back on his 27 years of life.
(So this is the end of my life...)
(What do I want to do in this one year...?)

Star Man decided he wanted to help Trapezoid Man and the others escape the island.
Not out of goodwill, but by elimination there was little else.
He decided to test fire and ice magic for the escape.
(How do I make it come out...?)
When he imagined flames coming from his hand, flames came from his hand.
(Eh... whoa... whoa!)
"Hah... hah... hah... hah..."

Star Man felt that using magic tired him as much as sprinting at full speed.
What's more, the flame from his hand was as weak as a candle's flame.
(If it costs this much stamina for this little, punching would be faster...)

It felt linked to his stamina and strength—the more he used it, the more tired he got,
and the stronger it seemed to grow.
(I'll try the others, too...)

When he imagined ice, a small ice shard came from his hand.
When he imagined dark flame, black flames came out.
(I've never seen anything like this. For now I understand what it is.)
Star Man decided to resume gathering acorns.

(It's still mostly cube‑shaped monsters.
Until now just standing and walking took everything I had, but now I'm fully recovered.
Maybe I should try fighting one here—there may be situations where I have to fight.)
Star Man slowly approached and tried throwing a stone.
(I'd like to hit it with a heavy rock, but I'm afraid it might bounce back at me...)
After thinking a bit, Star Man came up with a strategy.

He lured the monster to a ledge two meters high.
The monster could do nothing but jump.
Since it only came straight, staying up high let him attack one‑sided from close range.

Using the ledge, Star Man kept dropping rocks.
The monster's body was gradually destroyed and collapsed.
Eventually the monster stopped moving.

Star Man went over to the monster and examined it.
It felt like gelatin; when he poked it, it wobbled with a blorp.
(It smells unnatural. It feels dangerous to touch...)
He decided to wrap a piece in a leaf and bring it back.
